WaniKani_Meaning_Mnemonic: The say radical and the say kanji are the same!
WaniKani_Reading_Mnemonic: If you aren't sure what to say, just think about Genji (ã’ã‚“) and ask yourself, "What would Genji say?"
WaniKani_Reading_Info: Genji is a real smooth talker. In fact, he can talk his way out of anything. If you can just stay calm and think "What would Genji say?" before saying anything, you'll probably end up saying something cool instead of something lame.

chinese_mnemonics_deck__story: A pictogram of someone with a top hat saying a four letter word from their mouth after the censors have gotten a hold of it.
origin_of_ch_char_book: Woman writing with a brush pen (18thâ€“19th century) In modern China, this is the character that is used to signify reading a book: (æ›¸, ä¹¦, shu, book) On the top there is a hand, and underneath the character is the bottom of the tree (æœ¬, ben, root). Like the stump of a tree, a person holds a long, stubby pen tool. Below is a fire (ç«, huo, fire) burning for the ancestral rite, and a mouth that means words at the rite. This character describes someone recording the words of various people performing at the memorial service. It is now used to mean a book. (è«–, è®º, lun, essay; discuss) The left symbolizes a forthright statement like a spear (è¨€, yan, speak). Upper right corner is a roof or lid that collects something in it. And there are wood pieces with various records tied up together . The ancients have written a lot of records on bamboo sticks, and they discuss together whether these records are right or wrong. Therefore, this character has become to mean logical theory or a rational discussion.
humanum_full_description_en:
Jia Jinwen starts from " tongue " from " one ", adding a horizontal line on the tongue. One said that " one " refers to the symbol of things, and "words" come from the meaning of the tongue (Yu Shengwu). Later inscriptions on " tongue " and " one " were added with a short horizontal pen to form the " word " of later generations.

The oracle bone inscriptions are used as the original meaning, expressing words, such as "Zheng Yanqi is disease." It is also used as a sacrifice name.

Bronze inscriptions are also used as the original meaning to express speech, Zhongshan Wangding: "This is easy to say but difficult to do." It is also falsely called " Xin ", which means a feast, and Bo Juding: "With words (Xin), the king is an insider." "Zuo Zhuan. "The Thirty-one Years of Xi Gong": "Not Xin Qi Si" Du pre-note: "Xin Yu Yan Ye." Also used as a name.

"Guodian Chu Jian. "Mao Yi": "The Defilement of This Word", "Poetry. Daya. "Yi": "Baigui's defilement can still be grinded. The defilement of what is said cannot be done."

"Shuowen": "Speaking straight is talking about words, but talking hard is talking about words. From the mouth to the voice. All words belong to the language."

See also " yue ", " now ", " tongue ", " sound ", " meaning ".
humanum_short_description_en: Jia Jin inscription from " tongue " from " one ", which means that speaking comes from the tongue.

Jia Jinwen starts from " tongue" from " one", adding a horizontal line on the tongue. One said that " one" refers to the symbol of things, and "words" come from the meaning of the tongue (Yu Shengwu). Later inscriptions on " tongue" and " one" were added with a short horizontal pen to form the " word" of later generations. The oracle bone inscriptions are used as the original meaning, expressing words, such as "Zheng Yanqi is disease." It is also used as a sacrifice name. Bronze inscriptions are also used as the original meaning to express speech, Zhongshan Wangding: "This is easy to say but difficult to do." It is also falsely called " Xin", which means a feast, and Bo Juding: "With words (Xin), the king is an insider." "Zuo Zhuan. "The Thirty-one Years of Xi Gong": "Not Xin Qi Si" Du pre-note: "Xin Yu Yan Ye." Also used as a name. "Guodian Chu Jian. "Mao Yi": "The Defilement of This Word", "Poetry. Daya. "Yi": "Baigui's defilement can still be grinded. The defilement of what is said cannot be done." "Shuowen": "Speaking straight is talking about words, but talking hard is talking about words. From the mouth to the voice. All words belong to the language." See also " yue", " now", " tongue", " sound", " meaning".
